Award.AwardTitle: EAGER: Multiscale Analysis of Human Heart Cooling Protocols

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
MULTI-SCALE ANALYSIS OF COOLING PROTOCOLS FOR HUMAN HEARTS

The main current problem of organ transplantation is the relatively short time that organs can survive from the moment of their harvesting to the moment of their surgical transplantation into the recipient's body. In organ preservation, cold preservation is still considered as the best method. Lowering the temperatures of cells, tissues and organs lowers their chemical reaction rates, thus lowering their metabolic decay rate. In currently used standard heart cooling procedures, the extracted human heart is kept submerged in a container with saline solution at a temperature slightly above that of freezing water. The current limit for a heart to remain viable for transplantation using this method of cooling is only 4.5 hours, after which the heart is discarded. Consequently, a large number of viable donated hearts are discarded because the recipient of the heart lives too far away. The ultimate objective of this research is to extend the viability of the extracted human heart to more than 10.5 hours, which was recently computationally demonstrated by the PI as preliminarily feasible. This would provide more than 8 hours for air transport, thus enabling hearts to be transported for transplantation anywhere in the populated North American continent. The results of this project should provide an understanding of the proposed organ cooling protocols that are both viable and widely applicable.

The objective of this project is to apply advanced numerical analysis and optimization concepts of rapidly cooling human hearts to explore reducing metabolic decay and extending their use for the purpose of long distance transportation to the transplantation site. The focus will be on performing a multi-scale analysis of the conjugate heat transfer in realistic human hearts including epicardiac and intramural blood vessels. The risk is that adding this geometric and numerical complexity might not increase the cooling rate. As part of achieving this goal, the explanted heart should immediately begin a cooling process utilizing nearly-freezing water in order to cool the heart as uniformly and as fast as possible to minimize permanent damage of the heart muscle due to metabolism. In this preliminary research, coolant flow and the corresponding heat transfer in coronary blood vessels, branching intramural vessels and microcirculation in the heart muscle tissue will be included for the first time. By including these multiple length scale effects into the overall forced convection conjugate heat transfer analysis, it could be expected that the speed and uniformity of cooling of the realistic human hearts can be increased, thus decreasing further the metabolic decay and extending further the viability time limit available for transporting the extracted hearts.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The main findings of this mini-grant funded by the NSF are that it is practically inconsequential if we include the extracorporal blood vessels in the cooling topology of a human heart. In other words, the excessive additional amount of time needed to define the 3D geometry of these blood vessels, their appropriate discretization, and their proper interfacing with the 3D computational grid of the heart increase the usable time of a heart-alone geometry by only approximately 4 percent. The described excessive preparation time and approximately 1.5 orders of magnitude longer computing time further disqualify this type of detailed analysis from becoming a practical analysis tool in actual applications.

On the other hand, using a 3D Pennes equation instead of the classical unsteady 3D heat conduction equation in the entire heart tissue during the unsteady temperature field conjugate heat transfer analysis shows promise to increase the usable time of an extracted human heart to be up to 14 hours. The major drawback in this model is that we do not know the correct values of the local blood flow rate, convection heat transfer and metabolic rate heat sources. These unknown parameters could be evaluated using inverse parameter identification algorithms applied to experimentally measured local unsteady variations of temperature in the heart tissue.

Consequently, one of the implicit aspects of the research performed on this project is development of inverse parameter identification algorithms for determination of spatial distribution of thermo-physical properties of living tissues. Specifically, what is the spatial distribution of thermal capacity and thermal conductivity that is compatible with temperatures and/or heat fluxes measured on the boundaries of a given arbitrarily shaped object?  

The impact on society is probably the most important aspect of this project. The results of this research will lead to the eventual development of portable cooling hardware for explanted human hearts and other human organs and enable their long term transportation to the sites of actual Implantation without having to worry about freezing effects. Specifically, the current technology can preserve a human heart for 4.5 hours. The new forced convection cooling technology based on this research will be able to preserve human hearts for 11 to 14 hours and in such a way provide needed patience with transplant organs transported over the entire populated part of north and central America, Caribbean and most of Europe thus, potentially saving the lives of tens of thousands of critically ill patients.
